messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Contracting with a Learning Agent This work is funded by the European Union (ERC grant No. 101077862, Project: ALGOCONTRACT, PI: Inbal Talgam-Cohen, and ERC grant No. 740282, under the European Union‚Äôs Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme, PI: Noam Nisan), a Google Research Scholar award, a Foundations of Data Science Institute (FODSI) fellowship, the Israel Science Foundation (ISF grants No. 336/18 and No. 505/23 ), the Binational Science Foundation (BSF grant No. 2021680), and the National Science Foundation (NSF CAREER Grant CCF-1942497, PI: S. Matthew Weinberg).

Paper Abstract: Abstract Many real-life contractual relations differ completely from the clean, static model at the heart of principal-agent theory. Typically, they involve repeated strategic interactions of the principal and agent, taking place under uncertainty and over time. While appealing in theory, players seldom use complex dynamic strategies in practice, often preferring to circumvent complexity and approach uncertainty through learning. We initiate the study of repeated contracts with a learning agent, focusing on agents who achieve no-regret outcomes. Optimizing against a no-regret agent is a known open problem in general games; we achieve an optimal solution to this problem for a canonical contract setting, in which the agent‚Äôs choice among multiple actions leads to success/failure. The solution has a surprisingly simple structure: for some Œ±>0ùõº0\alpha>0, initially offer the agent a linear contract with scalar Œ±ùõº\alpha, then switch to offering a linear contract with scalar 00. This switch causes the agent to ‚Äúfree-fall‚Äù through their action space and during this time provides the principal with non-zero reward at zero cost. Despite apparent exploitation of the agent, this dynamic contract can leave both players better off compared to the best static contract. Our results generalize beyond success/failure, to arbitrary non-linear contracts which the principal rescales dynamically. Finally, we quantify the dependence of our results on knowledge of the time horizon, and are the first to address this consideration in the study of strategizing against learning agents.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Bayesian analysis of linear contracts",
        "Near-optimal no-regret learning for correlated equilibria in multi-player general-sum games",
        "Incomplete written contracts: Undescribable states of nature",
        "The multiplicative weights update method: A meta-algorithm and applications",
        "The nonstochastic multiarmed bandit problem",
        "Combinatorial agency",
        "Optimal collaterals in multi-enterprise investment networks",
        "Commitment without regrets: Online learning in Stackelberg security games",
        "Principal-agent reward shaping in MDPs",
        "Incomplete contracts and strategic ambiguity",
        "Regret minimization and the price of total anarchy",
        "From external to internal regret",
        "Contract Theory",
        "Selling to a no-regret buyer",
        "Is learning in games good for the learners?",
        "Regret analysis of stochastic and nonstochastic multi-armed bandit problems",
        "Selling to multiple no-regret buyers",
        "Mechanisms for a no-regret agent: Beyond the common prior",
        "Bayesian agency: Linear versus tractable contracts",
        "Multi-agent contract design: How to commission multiple agents with individual outcomes",
        "Prediction, learning, and games",
        "Learning approximately optimal contracts",
        "Dynamic games and dynamic contract theory",
        "Learning in auctions: Regret is hard, envy is easy",
        "Prior-free dynamic auctions with low regret buyers",
        "Strategizing against no-regret learners",
        "Combinatorial contracts",
        "Multi-agent contracts",
        "Combinatorial contracts beyond gross substitutes",
        "Ambiguous contracts",
        "Optimal no-regret learning of one-sided Lipschitz functions",
        "Simple versus optimal contracts",
        "The complexity of contracts",
        "On the convergence of regret minimization dynamics in concave games",
        "Correlated and coarse equilibria of single-item auctions",
        "Strategic classification in the dark",
        "The problematic employment dynamics of student internships",
        "Contracts under moral hazard and adverse selection",
        "The power of menus in contract design",
        "Learning in online principal-agent interactions: The power of menus",
        "Approximation to Bayes risk in repeated play",
        "No-regret learning in Bayesian games",
        "Adaptive contract design for crowdsourcing markets: Bandit algorithms for repeated principal-agent problems",
        "Aggregation and linearity in the provision of intertemporal incentives",
        "Limited liability and incentive contracting with ex-ante action choices",
        "Efficient algorithms for online decision problems",
        "How do classifiers induce agents to invest effort strategically?",
        "Auctions between regret-minimizing agents",
        "How and why to manipulate your own agent: On the incentives of users of learning agents",
        "The Theory of Incentives: The Principal-Agent Model",
        "Contract design for afforestation programs",
        "Optimization of scoring rules",
        "Learning and efficiency in games with dynamic population",
        "Strategizing against learners in Bayesian games",
        "Econometrics for learning agents",
        "Bid prediction in repeated auctions with learning",
        "Contracts with information acquisition, via scoring rules",
        "A continuous-time version of the principal-agent problem",
        "Introduction to multi-armed bandits",
        "No-regret learning and mixed nash equilibria: They do not mix",
        "On supermodular contracts and dense subgraphs",
        "Steering no-regret learners to optimal equilibria",
        "The sample complexity of online contract design"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Contracting with a Learning Agent This work is funded by the European Union (ERC grant No. 101077862, Project: ALGOCONTRACT, PI: Inbal Talgam-Cohen, and ERC grant No. 740282, under the European Union‚Äôs Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Programme, PI: Noam Nisan), a Google Research Scholar award, a Foundations of Data Science Institute (FODSI) fellowship, the Israel Science Foundation (ISF grants No. 336/18 and No. 505/23 ), the Binational Science Foundation (BSF grant No. 2021680), and the National Science Foundation (NSF CAREER Grant CCF-1942497, PI: S. Matthew Weinberg)., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
